Text.Value: But there is only one who truly counts, no? One whose favour you crave. One who knows the catastrophe that lurks 'twixt your ribs.
The ill effects may linger, I'm afraid. Not enough to hamper your mission, I hope.
Alas, not the role I've been given in this particular tale. I am but a bare cameo compared to the part that you must play. You and the orb.
Like moons make swell and wane the nescient seas, so too the sky-strewn gods ordain the tidal fates of mortal days.
Remain silent.
You know where you went wrong, Gale. We needn't dwell on that here and now. But even so, you're to be given a chance of redemption.
She would consider what she considers to be forgiveness.
I was bid to spare neither time nor my own self to find you. She sent me, Gale. You know of whom I speak.
Don't just gawp at me like the dregs of the fishmonger's stall - I've worn out quite some boot leather in order to track you down.
I am Mystra's servant. If this is what she asks of me, so be it.
Even the waves of fate can break upon the shores of will.
What other choice do I have?
Elminster?
You mean the orb. You mean I sacrifice myself.
It is done. Both charge and charm have been committed into your care.
With that, I've said my sorry piece, and need only bestow unto thee the charm I was bid.
Mystra is aware of the misadventures that have befallen you both. She knows of your strife with the Absolute, that most insidious of evils.
That's more magnanimous of her than I've grown accustomed to. The catch being?
Mystra has granted me the power to stop the clock, as it were, on the orb's rush to overpower you. Instead, you will be able to unleash its lethal combustion at will.
Whatever she can grant unto you is infinitely better than whatever you cling to now.
Hmm, yes. This shall suffice.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Glancing around at the general camp area.

Text.Value: The very same, Gale. And a fair bit miffed he is, too, finding himself forced to expose his best pair of boots to so many miles of country road on your behalf.
You promised me plain talk, Elminster. Make it plainer still, or we're done here.
Ah, finally he stirs. True adventurers get up with the lark, I always say, but if there are larks to be found in these lands, they must fancy themselves akin to nightingales.
My'Nahastra Mystra'Ryl. E'Deelion Thras'Anas'Tthra.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: [SCENE] He's disarming a magic orb within Gale's chest, close to his heart. Elminster gestures towards Gale's heart with an open palm, moving the hand in a small ircular motion, as if soothing or containing the orb within with a charm.
EditorData.VFXTags: Elminster magic effect on hands and on Gale

Text.Value: Mystra would consider... forgiveness?
Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.
Keep listening.
Farewell, my friend.
That's the cost of Mystra's good graces? Martyrdom?
Young man, has your sojourn away from Waterdeep washed away your decorum as well as your patience?
The orb. That constant reminder of your past failings. The instrument of your slow, sad, inevitable destruction. It can instead redeem you.
But I suppose, after all the calamity that's been laid at your feet, you can be forgiven raw nerves and a sharp tongue...

It brings me no pleasure saying this, my friend, but such is Mystra's will. Yours must be the sacrifice that will undo the Absolute. And for your sacrifice, you will be redeemed - such is Mystra's promise.
Say nothing. Wait for him to explain himself.
You must find the Heart of the Absolute, whatever that may be, and use yourself as the catalyst that will burn it from this world.
Remember who she is, Gale. Mortal death is but a passing chapter to a goddess - and to those who win her favour.
Mystra would consider... forgiveness?
*Your previous encounter with the old wizard seems to have left him unflustered - and unmarked.*
Mystra sent you? Why?
Your clear-mindedness is a testament to yourself, Gale.
The catch being the exact definition of redemption in Mystra's eyes, and the labour you must undertake in order to attain it.
That is why I have come here to charge you, Gale, with its destruction. It is Mystra's belief that only you can.

You must know that the Absolute is more dangerous than you can possibly conceive. It threatens all who live - even those who are undying. It threatens the gods, the Weave, the very fabric of the universe itself.
As you say.
Mystra - the message and the charge I bring you are hers.
You mean the orb. You mean I sacrifice myself.

EditorData.NodeContext: Weary resignation. He's being asked on a suicide mission.

Text.Value: You underestimate me, Elminster. 'She' could be any number of acquaintances.
Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.
I took the liberty of enlisting your cadaverous co-traveller to revive you. You truly should take much better care of yourself, m'boy.
And yet - a notion born in lonely hours - come ebb, come flow, come all that is beyond the breadth of our dominion: be a moon unto yourself.
I could possibly put an end to the Absolute - if you aided me.
You could flee from Mystra's calling. Live the life of a hermit once again, and succumb to the orb all the same. Only, it will be a death without purpose.
*Your previous encounter with the old wizard was most likely a simulacrum - the figure before you may well be too.*
A shame that we did not cross paths sooner. The orb's thirst for magic is now quenched, yet it already inflicted some damage while you tried to forge ahead.

Synopsis: Triggers either as an OOM or an AOM when Elminster is already in the camp, or a CFM (if the player skips Elminster altogether).
